articles.headline: Germany Shuts 7 Plants as Europe Plans Safety Tests
articles.snippet: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said that seven older plants that began operating before 1980 would be temporarily closed.
articles.abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said that seven older plants that began operating before 1980 would be temporarily closed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Germany on Tuesday became the first European country to shut nuclear plants in the wake of the crisis in Japan as the European Union made plans to test all 143 nuclear power plants in its 27 countries.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Judy Dempsey

articles.headline: Libyan Oil Buys Allies for Qaddafi
articles.snippet: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has sprinkled billions of dollars around Africa, helping him recruit mercenaries and blunt criticism.
articles.abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has sprinkled billions of dollars around Africa, helping him recruit mercenaries and blunt criticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — Elhadj Maiga is a Qaddafi recruiter and a proud one at that, scrambling to assemble a pipeline of young men from Mali to go and fight for The Great Leader.

articles.headline: Northrop to Spin Off Shipyards
articles.snippet: Northrop Grumman approved the spinoff of its shipbuilding operations in order to focus on more profitable sectors.
articles.abstract: Northrop Grumman approved the spinoff of its shipbuilding operations in order to focus on more profitable sectors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Northrop Grumman’s board approved the spinoff of its struggling shipyards to stockholders after making changes to ease Navy concerns about the deal, Pentagon and industry officials said on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Disasters’ Costs to Fall on Japan’s Government
articles.snippet: The losses in Japan as a result of the earthquake and resulting tsunami are expected to exceed $100 billion.
articles.abstract: The losses in Japan as a result of the earthquake and resulting tsunami are expected to exceed $100 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apart from an expected $35 billion in insurance claims from last week’s earthquake, the financial losses in Japan will probably fall most heavily on the Japanese government once it tallies the damage from the tsunami and the nuclear disaster.

articles.headline: Last Defense at Troubled Reactors: 50 Japanese Workers
articles.snippet: A small crew of technicians, braving radiation and fire, became perhaps Japan’s last chance of preventing a broader nuclear catastrophe.
articles.abstract: A small crew of technicians, braving radiation and fire, became perhaps Japan’s last chance of preventing a broader nuclear catastrophe.
articles.lead_paragraph: A small crew of technicians, braving radiation and fire, became the only people remaining at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station on Tuesday — and perhaps Japan’s last chance of preventing a broader nuclear catastrophe.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Stocks End Lower as Traders Focus on Japan Crisis
articles.snippet: With investors on a hair-trigger over Japan, American and European stock markets ended sharply lower again.
articles.abstract: With investors on a hair-trigger over Japan, American and European stock markets ended sharply lower again.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was no respite for weary investors Wednesday as deepening worries about the nuclear crisis in Japan prompted another sharp sell-off, leaving stocks in negative territory for the year.

articles.headline: U.S. Drones Fight Mexican Drug Trade
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has begun sending drones deep into Mexico to gather intelligence on trafficking.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has begun sending drones deep into Mexico to gather intelligence on trafficking.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stepping up its involvement in Mexico’s drug war, the Obama administration has begun sending drones deep into Mexican territory to gather intelligence that helps locate major traffickers and follow their networks, according to American and Mexican officials.
articles.byline: By Ginger Thompson and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: U.S. Calls Radiation ‘Extremely High;’ Sees Japan Nuclear Crisis Worsening
articles.snippet: The chairman of the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission gave a bleaker appraisal of the threat, but Japanese officials played down the concerns.
articles.abstract: The chairman of the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission gave a bleaker appraisal of the threat, but Japanese officials played down the concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission gave a far bleaker appraisal on Wednesday of the threat posed by Japan’s nuclear crisis than the Japanese government had offered. He said American officials believed that the damage to at least one crippled reactor was much more serious than Tokyo had acknowledged, and he advised Americans to stay much farther away from the plant than the perimeter established by Japanese authorities.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Matthew L. Wald and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Hushed Deal Frees C.I.A. Contractor in Pakistan
articles.snippet: Raymond A. Davis, accused of murder, was freed after secret talks that led to a payment to the victims’ families.
articles.abstract: Raymond A. Davis, accused of murder, was freed after secret talks that led to a payment to the victims’ families.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — A C.I.A. security officer jailed for killing two Pakistanis on a crowded Lahore street was released Wednesday after weeks of secret negotiations between American and Pakistani officials, a pledge of millions of dollars in “blood money” to the victims’ families, and quiet political pressure by Pakistani officials on the courts.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Mark Mazzetti
